introduction

introduction.Rmd
library(REnergy)

The REnergy package provides tools to explore renewable energy trends in Australia from 2010 to 2023. This package includes a Shiny app for interactive data visualization and functions for analyzing investment and energy production data. It is designed to help analysts, researchers, and policymakers gain insights into renewable energy investment patterns and production in Australia.

In this vignette, we’ll walk you through the main features of the package and show you how to get started.

Installation

To install the development version of REnergy from GitHub, use:

#install.packages("remotes") # Uncomment if 'remotes' is not installed
remotes::install_github("ETC5523-2024/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-akshatamhaski")

Using the Shiny App The main feature of the REnergy package is a Shiny app that allows you to explore renewable energy data interactively. To launch the Shiny app, load the package and call the launch_shiny_app() function:

library(REnergy)
launch_shiny_app()

This will open the Shiny app in your default web browser. The app includes the following features:

Investment Trends: Select an energy type to view the total investments over time (2010-2023). Energy Production by Type: Select a year to view a breakdown of renewable energy production by type.

Accessing the Cleaned Data If you prefer working with data directly, you can access the cleaned data included in this package. The dataset contains information on investment in USD and energy production in GWh, filtered for Australia from 2010 to 2023.

To load the cleaned data:

data("cleaned_data", package = "REnergy")
head(cleaned_data)
#>   year   country energy_type investments_usd production_g_wh
#> 1 2008 Australia  Geothermal       636188589       22205.069
#> 2 2020 Australia       Hydro      3891812730        3386.115
#> 3 2009 Australia       Solar       338009756       40218.011
#> 4 2011 Australia       Hydro      1638287454       73276.902
#> 5 2014 Australia       Hydro      1187775824       11187.967
#> 6 2020 Australia     Biomass       413571723       64826.378

Example Analysis Let’s say you want to analyze total investments in different renewable energy types over time. Here’s a simple example using the dplyr package:

library(dplyr)
#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.3.3
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

# Summarize total investments by energy type
investment_summary <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(energy_type) %>%
  summarize(total_investment = sum(investments_usd, na.rm = TRUE))
print(investment_summary)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 2
#>   energy_type total_investment
#>   <chr>                  <dbl>
#> 1 Biomass        250019041153.
#> 2 Geothermal     237225699909.
#> 3 Hydro          284204304563.
#> 4 Solar          223976704026.
#> 5 Wind           214590698042.

This example groups the data by energy_type and calculates the total investment for each type, helping you understand which types of renewable energy received the most funding.

Conclusion The REnergy package provides an interactive way to explore renewable energy trends in Australia, using both the Shiny app and direct data access. This vignette has shown you how to install the package, launch the Shiny app, and use the cleaned dataset for custom analyses.

For further details on specific functions and data, refer to the reference manual or check out the function documentation within R.

Developed by Akshata Mhaski.
